title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 4.120 - Executive order no. 120: establishing the statewide anti-drug abuse council
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 4.120 - Executive order no. 120: establishing the statewide anti-drug abuse council

State Regulations
WHEREAS, the phenomenon of drug abuse and the crime, violence, corruption and human suffering it engenders is universally recognized
as one of the most urgent and intractable problems of our time; WHEREAS, this evil has spread throughout our society, affecting rich and poor, young and old, urban, suburban and rural communities
alike; WHEREAS, the evils spawned by drug abuse manifest
themselves in the form of crime, corruption, disease, drug addiction, family
disruption and domestic violence, the blighting of communities, the spread of
AIDS, and a loss of public confidence in the ability of the institutions of
government to address these evils; WHEREAS, the multiplicity of problems engendered by the
abuse of drugs, including alcohol, demands a most vigorous and concerted
response on many fronts simultaneously, addressing the needs for the
improvement and enforcement of the drug laws, the development and provision of
substance abuse treatment for drug dependent persons, scientific research into
the causes and cure of drug addiction, education of the public, especially
young people, to the dangers of drug abuse and the consequences of drug crime, and efforts to address the consequences to the public health and the public
health care system imposed by rampant drug abuse; WHEREAS, the People of the State of New York, through their

State and local governments, through their schools and through their voluntary
and civic associations are in fact already committed to an all out campaign
against drugs; WHEREAS, the People of the State of New York have and will
continue to devote tremendous public resources and energies to the campaign
against drugs; WHEREAS, at any time, and especially in time of strained
public resources, strict accountability and solid assurance of the careful and
intelligent expenditure of public resources must be maintained by the officers
and agencies entrusted by the People with the conduct of public affairs; WHEREAS, the effectiveness of our drug abuse control
efforts and the assurance of the effective and prudent expenditure of public
resources requires the assessment, improvement and coordination of the programs
and policies of our law enforcement, substance and alcohol abuse, education, health and other public agencies which constitute aspects of our campaign
against drugs; WHEREAS, the involvement of the private sector, including
community-based groups who minister to the needs of the drug and alcohol
dependent, who work with youth, who represent parents and teachers, and who
work together for civic and neighborhood improvement or for educational or
charitable purposes, is essential if we are to fully mobilize all of the
resources, the determination and the creative energy of our society; WHEREAS, an effort of such magnitude and consequence as our
war on drugs requires clear focus, effective direction, close coordination and
continuity that are best provided by the establishment of a council of those

State officials who are charged with the execution of the State's policies and
programs in the areas of law enforcement, education, drug and alcohol abuse
prevention and treatment and the public health; NOW, THEREFORE, I, MARIO M. CUOMO, Governor of the State of

New York, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and Laws
of the State of New York, do hereby establish the Statewide Anti-Drug Abuse

Council. I. Membership

The members of the Council shall be the Lieutenant

Governor, who shall be the Chairperson of the Council, the State Director of

Criminal Justice, the Commissioner of Education, the Commissioner of Health, the Director of Substance Abuse Services and the Director of Alcoholism and

Alcohol Abuse. II. Powers
and Responsibilities

The Statewide Anti-Drug Abuse Council shall: 1. Review and assess the extent and
effectiveness of current State agencies' policies and programs addressing all
facets of drug enforcement, treatment, education, prevention and drug and
alcohol related public health matters; 2. Identify areas of duplication of effort, inefficient overlap and inconsistent policies and programs among agencies
charged with drug enforcement, treatment, education, prevention, rehabilitation
and drug and alcohol related public health matters; 3. Develop a comprehensive strategy to
improve the effectiveness and coordination of the efforts of State agencies
charged with drug enforcement, treatment, education, prevention, rehabilitation
and public health matters; 4. Develop a system for coordinating the implementation, monitoring the
performance and evaluating the effectiveness of State efforts to reduce drug
trafficking and related crime, drug and alcohol abuse and related health and
social problems and to improve drug education and prevention; 5. Plan long-range and short-term drug
control strategies from a systemwide perspective, taking into account the
enforcement, education, prevention, treatment, rehabilitation, health and
research needs of the State and its communities; 6. Coordinate the activities of all State
agencies charged with, or affected by, the implementation of drug program
initiatives; 7. Review drug-related
budgetary and programmatic initiatives of State agencies from a systemwide
perspective and recommend priorities, modifications and improvements; 8. Act as the Governor's liaison with private
sector drug treatment, counselling and rehabilitation providers, educators, scientists, physicians and academics, parents groups, crime victims services
providers, advocates for youth and for the drug and alcohol dependent, and
voluntary charitable, religious, educational and public service associations
and other groups involved or seeking involvement in a strong and growing
public/private partnership to advance drug and alcohol abuse treatment, prevention and education efforts; 9. Consult with local governments and their
criminal justice, education, public health and drug and alcohol abuse agencies
regarding their recommendations for improvements to drug control efforts and
initiatives; 10. Review and assess
the experience of other states, the Federal Government and of other nations in
the development of programs and initiatives to address aspects of the drug
problem; 11. Identify, promote and
publicize anti-drug abuse programs and initiatives found to be of particular
merit; 12. Make a special and
concerted effort to encourage programs and initiatives in every community that
effectively alert young people to the dangers and the consequences of drug
abuse and drug crime; and
13. Promote strict accountability at every level of government and assure the
effective and prudent expenditure of public resources through the continual
evaluation, assessment, improvement and coordination of the programs and
policies of law enforcement, substance and alcohol abuse, education, health and
other public agencies charged with the conduct of the campaign against
drugs. III. Personnel

The Statewide Anti-Drug Abuse Council shall be authorized
to use existing staff and resources of State agencies, which are hereby
directed to render full cooperation and assistance to the Council. IV. Reports

The Council shall prepare periodic reports to the Governor
on its progress in developing effective strategies to address the far-reaching
effects of drug abuse. To assure timely coordination of its proposals with the
preparation of the Executive Budget and the development of necessary
legislative initiatives, the Council shall provide detailed reports on its
activities and make its recommendations on anti-drug abuse strategies to the

Governor no later than October 1, 1989, and annually thereafter. Signed: Mario M. CuomoDated: January 20, 1989
